image.caption: Collection of the U.S. House of Representatives

profileText: A Representative from Texas; born in Henderson, Rusk County, Tex., May 6, 1931; attended the Rusk County public schools; graduated from Henderson High School, 1949; attended Kilgore Junior College; B.B.A., University of Texas, Austin, 1954; served in United States Army, 1954-1956; coached football and track, Henderson High School, 1957-1959; business salesman, 1959; banking, 1962; officer and director in five Texas banks, and two manufacturing companies; special assistant to United States Representative W.R. Poage, 1972-1974; elected as a Democrat to the Ninety-sixth and to the five succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1979-January 3, 1991); was not a candidate for renomination in 1990 to the One Hundred Second Congress; died on December 8, 2000 in Arlington, Va.; interment in Rusk County Memorial Gardens, Henderson, Rusk County, Tex.

researchRecord.name: ca. 1979-1989, 237 linear feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Congressman Marvin Leath were deposited at the Poage Library in 1991 after Leath left office. One hundred sixty boxes were sent from Washington, DC, but 48 boxes were lost in transit. The materials came organized by the congressional office. The bulk of the boxes (90 boxes)contain numbered correspondence files, with 63 notebooks of replies and a 7-notebook correspondence index. Unfortunately the numbered system used by the office was not transferred with the papers. The correspondence are dated throughout his service in Congress, from 1981-1990. The next largest type of material are 10 boxes of sponsored/cosponsored legislation. These also date from 1989-1990. The remainder consists of press releases and clippings, speeches, invitations, newsletters, financial papers [budgets and expense reports] and several notebooks containing his personal voting record. Framed photos and plagues that make up the last 6 boxes were received in October, 1996 when Mr. Leath's office was relocating to Virginia.
